text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning:

- State-owned oil company Statoil will give almost one million crowns towards rebuilding flood-damaged areas in Poland. The company's Polish subsidiary, the Reitan group, has already donated food to the areas. Statoil owns 47 service stations in Poland.
- Three key figures in the Justice Ministry have quit in the last few months. Justice Minister Gerd-Liv Valla is perceived as authoritarian, lacking dynamism and extremely difficult to work with.

- Minister for Transport and Communications Sissel Roenbeck gave 3.35 million crowns to Marintek to research gas-driven buses in Trondheim. The ministry has put aside 11 million crowns for research into cost-effective and environmental solutions in the transport sector.

- Tourism and transport associations are against value added tax being put on hotel and travel bills. The Finance Department is considering adding VAT to all services while reducing the rate by 1.5 percentage points. Knut Almquist in the tourism association says extra VAT will have dramatic consequences for business.

- Christiania Bank og Kreditkasse ASA has taken over technology company Oceanor AS, saving the Trondheim-based group from bankruptcy. Christiania Bank is expected to find a new owner for Oceanor in the next two weeks.

- In the first half of 1997 the number of passengers using express coastal ferry services rose 6.7 percent to 188,000 and is expected to rise to 400,000 before the end of the year. Lower prices, new ships and increased international marketing is giving results.
